quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we dig into examples of how people are using ChatGPT and the new GPTs and other open AI APIs in their work and their life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights practical, real-world application areas practitioners can learn from and replicate.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Logan shares some really interesting advice on how to get better at prompt engineering.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Flags that the episode will include actionable guidance for improving prompt engineering skills.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also get into how OpenAI operates internally, how they ship so quickly, and the two key attributes they look for in the people that they hire, plus, where Logan sees the biggest opportunities for new products and new startups building on their APIs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to operational and hiring heuristics plus startup opportunity areas that can inform builders and leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you can believe it, ChatGPT launched just over a year ago and transformed the way that we think about AI and what it means for our products and our lives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A time-based data point framing the speed and magnitude of change practitioners should account for in planning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're a data person, you probably have to jump between different tools to run queries, build visualizations, write Python, and send around a lot of screenshots and CSV files.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a common workflow bottleneck practitioners can address by consolidating tools and reducing handoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Its powerful Notebook UI lets you analyze data in SQL, Python or no code in any combination and work together with live multiplayer and version control.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology for analytics work: mix modalities (SQL/Python/no-code) while treating analysis as collaborative, versioned software.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And now Hex's AI tools can generate queries and code, create visualizations, and even kickstart a whole analysis for you, all from natural language prompts.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable idea: use natural-language prompting to accelerate analysis setup, code generation, and visualization creation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Join the hundreds of data teams like Notion, All Trails, Loom, Mixpanel, and Algolia using Hex every day to make their work more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of recognizable teams using the tool, serving as a credibility/data point for adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whimsical helps product managers build clarity and shared understanding faster with tools designed for solving product challenges.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A memorable product-work mental model: optimize for clarity and shared understanding as the core output of product work.

quotes.topic_title: Inside OpenAI during the board weekend
quotes.text: I think it was super shocking because I think, and this is a perspective a lot of folks share, everybody had and continues to have such deep trust in Sam and Greg and our leadership team that it was just very surprising.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Highlights how high-trust leadership can make sudden governance changes especially destabilizing—and why maintaining trust is a critical organizational asset.

quotes.topic_title: Inside OpenAI during the board weekend
quotes.text: And we're also a very, as far as company cultures go, very transparent and very open. So when there's problems or there's things going on, we tend to hear about them.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Points to transparency as an operating norm that practitioners can emulate to reduce rumor, increase alignment, and surface issues earlier.

quotes.topic_title: Inside OpenAI during the board weekend
quotes.text: I think the thing that surprised me the most was just how quickly everybody got back to business.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A memorable observation about organizational resilience—how quickly a team can return to execution after a shock can be a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Inside OpenAI during the board weekend
quotes.text: And really it was like people laser focused and back to work, and I think that speaks to the caliber of our team and everybody who's just so excited about building towards the mission that we're building towards.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Connects rapid recovery to mission focus and team quality—useful for leaders designing culture and hiring for execution under uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Inside OpenAI during the board weekend
quotes.text: I think a lot of companies would've had the potential to truly be derailed for some non-trivial amount of time by this, and everybody was just right back to it, which I love.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A counterfactual benchmark practitioners can use to evaluate their own org’s ability to absorb disruption without losing momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Aftereffects: cohesion and timing of the crisis
quotes.text: One of my takeaways was I'm actually very grateful that this happened when it happened.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Reframes a crisis as a strategically valuable “early warning” event rather than purely negative.

quotes.topic_title: Aftereffects: cohesion and timing of the crisis
quotes.text: I think fast-forward five or 10 years, if something like this would've happened and we hadn't gone through the hopeful upcoming work transformation and all those changes that are going to happen, I think it would've been a little bit, or potentially much worse, of an outcome.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Offers a timing-based risk model: disruptions are less damaging before major transformations and higher-stakes maturity.

quotes.topic_title: Aftereffects: cohesion and timing of the crisis
quotes.text: So I'm glad that things happened when the stakes are a little bit lower.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway for leaders: treat lower-stakes periods as opportunities to stress-test org resilience.

quotes.topic_title: Aftereffects: cohesion and timing of the crisis
quotes.text: So I think we've had these events that have really brought the company together cross-functionally, so hopefully all the future ones will be really exciting things like GPT five, whenever that comes, and stuff like that.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Highlights a cohesion mechanism: shared “events” (launches/crises) create cross-functional bonding in fast-growing orgs.

quotes.topic_title: New AI interfaces beyond chat
quotes.text: The things that are getting me most excited are these new interfaces around AI, like the Rabbit R-1.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Points practitioners toward exploring emerging AI-first interfaces (including dedicated hardware) rather than defaulting to chat.

quotes.topic_title: New AI interfaces beyond chat
quotes.text: it really blows my mind to think about how chat is the predominant way that folks are using AI today.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that chat is the “end state” UI, encouraging teams to look for post-chat interaction models.

quotes.topic_title: New AI interfaces beyond chat
quotes.text: they're sort of building this infinite canvas experience and you can imagine how, as you're interacting with an AI on a daily basis, you might want to jump over to your infinite canvas, which the AI has filled in all the details and you might see a reference to a file and to a video and all of these different things.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Offers a concrete UX pattern—an AI-populated “infinite canvas” that organizes multimodal artifacts (files, videos, references) beyond chat threads.

quotes.topic_title: New AI interfaces beyond chat
quotes.text: It actually makes a lot more sense for us as humans to see stuff in that type of format than, I think, just listing out a bunch of stuff in chat.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Actionable product guidance: consider spatial/visual layouts for AI outputs when comprehension and navigation matter more than conversational flow.

quotes.topic_title: New AI interfaces beyond chat
quotes.text: I think 2024 is the year of multimodal AI, but it's also the year that people really push the boundaries of some of these new UX paradigms around AI.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A planning heuristic for builders: prioritize multimodal capabilities and invest in new UX paradigms (not just better chat) as a 2024 product bet.

quotes.topic_title: Where founders should build vs OpenAI
quotes.text: I think we're deeply focused on these very, very general use cases like the general reasoning capabilities, the general coding, the general writing abilities.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Clarifies OpenAI’s strategic focus so founders can avoid building directly in the company’s core lane.

quotes.topic_title: Where founders should build vs OpenAI
quotes.text: And I think a great example of this is actually Harvey. I don't know if you've seen Harvey, but it's this legal AI use case where they're building custom models and tools to help lawyers and people at legal firms and stuff like that.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of a defensible vertical approach (legal) built on top of general models.

quotes.topic_title: Where founders should build vs OpenAI
quotes.text: I think the challenge for them is they are going to end up directly competing against us in those spaces and I think there's enough room for a lot of people to be successful, but to me you shouldn't be surprised when we end up launching some general purpose agent product because, again, we're sort of building that with GPTs today and versus we're not going to launch some of these varied verticalized products.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A practical warning: general-purpose assistants/agents are likely to face direct competition from OpenAI, while vertical products are less likely to.

quotes.topic_title: Where founders should build vs OpenAI
quotes.text: We're not going to launch an AI sales agent. That's just not what we're building towards.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A crisp positioning statement founders can use to justify building vertical agents (e.g., sales) without expecting OpenAI to copy the exact product.

quotes.topic_title: Where founders should build vs OpenAI
quotes.text: And I think if you're going to try and solve this very general, if you're going to try to build the next general assistant to compete with something like ChatGPT, it has to be so radically different.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Sets a high bar and a clear differentiation requirement for anyone attempting to compete in general-purpose assistant markets.

quotes.topic_title: Using GPTs and AI to boost company efficiency
quotes.text: I think engineering is actually one of the highest leverage things that you could be using AI to do today and really unlocking, probably on the order of at least a 50% improvement, especially for some of the lower hanging fruit software engineering tasks.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A concrete, practitioner-relevant estimate of where AI delivers the biggest near-term productivity gains (especially on routine engineering work).

quotes.topic_title: Using GPTs and AI to boost company efficiency
quotes.text: I think one of the general challenges with ChatGPT is it gives a decent answer for a lot of different use cases, but oftentimes it's not particular enough to the voice of your company or the nuance of the work that you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Explains why generic AI usage plateaus and why teams should push toward company-specific nuance to get real leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Using GPTs and AI to boost company efficiency
quotes.text: And I think now with GPTs and people who are using the teams in ChatGPT and Enterprise in ChatGPT, they can actually build those things, incorporate the nuance of their own company, and make solving those tasks much, much more domain specific.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: use GPTs to encode company voice/constraints so outputs become reliably useful for internal workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Using GPTs and AI to boost company efficiency
quotes.text: One is he built a GPT that helps write ads for Facebook and Google just gives you ideas for ads to run, and so that takes a little load off the marketing team or the growth team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific internal GPT example that directly reduces human workload by generating ad variants on demand.

quotes.topic_title: Using GPTs and AI to boost company efficiency
quotes.text: And then he built another GPT that delivers experiment results, kind of like a data scientist, with here's the result of this experiment. And then you could talk to it and ask for like, "Hey, how much longer do you think we should run this for," or, "What might this imply about our product," and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete pattern for operationalizing analytics: turn experiment readouts into an interactive assistant for decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Logan’s planning GPT for metrics and timelines
quotes.text: I took a bunch of the... I'll see if I can make it public after this and send you a link, but took a bunch of the examples from that and went in and put some of those suggestions into the GPT, and then now when I do any of my planning of I want to build this thing, I put it through and have it generate a timeline, generate all the specifics of what are the metrics and success that I'm looking for, who might be some important cross-functional stakeholders to include in the planning process, all that stuff, and it's been helpful.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A concrete, reusable planning workflow: encode best-practice planning prompts into a private GPT to consistently produce timelines, success metrics, and stakeholder lists.

quotes.topic_title: Logan’s planning GPT for metrics and timelines
quotes.text: there's this whole genre of prompt engineering. It feels like it's one of these really emerging skills.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights prompt engineering as a distinct, learnable skill area practitioners can invest in to get better outcomes from AI tools.

quotes.topic_title: Logan’s planning GPT for metrics and timelines
quotes.text: I actually saw a startup hiring a prompt engineer, one of the startups I've invested in, and I think that's going to blow a lot of people's minds that there's this new job that's emerging.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific example signaling real market demand for prompt engineering as a role, not just a buzzword.

quotes.topic_title: Logan’s planning GPT for metrics and timelines
quotes.text: And I know the idea is this won't last forever, that in theory AI will be so smart you don't need to really think about how to be smart about asking it for things you need it to do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counterintuitive take: prompt engineering may be a temporary advantage as models improve, shaping how people should invest in the skill.

quotes.topic_title: Prompt engineering: context, techniques, and examples
quotes.text: Crap in crap out. If you ask a pretty basic question, you're going to get a pretty basic response.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for why prompt quality directly determines output quality, pushing practitioners to invest in specificity.

quotes.topic_title: Prompt engineering: context, techniques, and examples
quotes.text: My whole position on this is prompt engineering is a very human thing.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Reframes prompting as normal human communication—set expectations that models need the same context and clarity people do.

quotes.topic_title: Prompt engineering: context, techniques, and examples
quotes.text: It's the reason that you get super generic responses sometimes is because people forget they need to put that context in the model.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Actionable diagnosis for generic outputs: missing user/task/background context rather than model capability.

quotes.topic_title: Prompt engineering: context, techniques, and examples
quotes.text: It wants to. It so deeply wants to answer your question. It doesn't care that it doesn't have enough context. It's the most eager person in the world you could imagine to answer the question, and without that context it's just hard to do, to give anything a value.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that the model won’t “push back” when it lacks info—so you must proactively supply constraints and sources.

quotes.topic_title: Prompt engineering: context, techniques, and examples
quotes.text: If we got t-shirts printed, they should say, "Context is all you need. Context is the only thing that matters."
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Memorable maxim emphasizing the highest-leverage prompt improvement: add relevant context before anything else.

quotes.topic_title: GPTs and the GPT Store: what it is
quotes.text: So GPT kind of changes this where you take all that important context, you put it into the model to begin with, and then people can go and chat with essentially a custom version of ChatGPT.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A practical mental model for GPTs: package the context up front so others can reuse the workflow without recreating the setup conversation.

quotes.topic_title: GPTs and the GPT Store: what it is
quotes.text: And the thing that's really interesting is you can upload files, you can give it custom instructions, you can add all these different tools.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Actionable checklist of the core building blocks practitioners can use to make a GPT reliably useful (files + instructions + tools).

quotes.topic_title: GPTs and the GPT Store: what it is
quotes.text: You can also, for more advanced use cases if you're a developer, you can connect it to external APIs so you can connect it to the Notion API or Gmail or all these different things, and have it actually take actions on your behalf.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Concrete example of moving from “chat” to “do” by wiring GPTs into real systems via API actions.

quotes.topic_title: GPTs and the GPT Store: what it is
quotes.text: Going back to context is all you need, this is very true in the context of GPTs, and if you give it enough context, you can solve much more interesting problems.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A memorable principle practitioners can apply immediately: better outcomes often come from richer context, not more prompting tricks.

quotes.topic_title: GPTs and the GPT Store: what it is
quotes.text: I think monetization, when it comes to the store later this quarter, I think is going to be extremely exciting when people can get paid based on who's using their GPT.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Specific monetization mechanism preview: payouts tied to usage, shaping how builders should think about distribution and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite GPT examples: Zapier and learning tutors
quotes.text: All of the stuff that Zapier has done with GPTs is the most useful stuff that you could imagine.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete benchmark for “useful” GPTs: real-world integrations that unlock practical outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite GPT examples: Zapier and learning tutors
quotes.text: you can actually, as a third party developer, integrate Zapier without knowing how to code into your GPT.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Actionable takeaway that non-coders can still add powerful automation capabilities via Zapier integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite GPT examples: Zapier and learning tutors
quotes.text: basically all 5,000 connections that are possible with Zapier today, you can bring into your GPT and essentially enable it to do anything.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A specific data point illustrating how integrations can massively expand a GPT’s capabilities surface area.

quotes.topic_title: Favorite GPT examples: Zapier and learning tutors
quotes.text: It's described as, "Learn everything about anything," and basically, I think, it's kind of this Socratic method of helping you learn stuff.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable learning framework (Socratic tutoring) as a standout GPT pattern for education.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Telling the story of your product is hard and customers want you to show them your product, not just talk about it or gate it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical positioning principle: prioritize showing over explaining, and remove friction like gating to improve adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Arcade, they achieved a 2X higher conversion rate for demos and saw five times more engagement than videos.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete performance benchmark suggesting interactive demos can materially outperform video for engagement and conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: On top of that, they built the demo 10 times faster than before.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A strong speed/efficiency data point that supports investing in tooling to reduce demo creation cycle time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With browser-based recording Arcade is the no-code solution for building personalized demos at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: An actionable method: use browser-based, no-code workflows to scale personalized demos without engineering bottlenecks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Arcade offers product customization options, designer approved editing tools and rich insights about how your viewers engage every step of the way.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A useful checklist for evaluating demo platforms: customization, quality editing, and step-level engagement analytics.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships fast: agency, urgency, and Slack
quotes.text: finding people who are high agency and work with urgency is one of the most... If I was hiring five people today, those are some of the top two characteristics that I would look for in people because you can take on the world if you have people who have high agency and not needing to either get 50 people's different consensus, because you have people who you trust with high agency and they can just go and do the thing, I think, is one of the most... It is the most important thing, I'm pretty sure, if you were to distill it down.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A hiring heuristic and operating model: prioritize agency + urgency to reduce consensus overhead and increase execution speed.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships fast: agency, urgency, and Slack
quotes.text: They see a problem and they go and tackle it. They hear something from our customers about a challenge that they're having and they're already pushing on what the solution for them is and not waiting for all the other things to happen that I think traditional companies are stuck behind because they're like, "Oh, let's check with all these seven different departments to try to get feedback on this." People just go and do it and solve the problem.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A concrete behavioral definition of “high agency” that practitioners can use to set expectations and evaluate teams.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships fast: agency, urgency, and Slack
quotes.text: I think the assistants API that we released for dev day, we continue to get this feedback from developers that people wanted these higher levels of abstraction on top of our existing APIs, and a bunch of folks on the team just came together and were like, "Hey, let's put together what the plan would look like to build something like this," And then very quickly came together and actually built the actual API that now powers so many people's assistant applications that are out there.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A specific example of rapid, customer-feedback-driven cross-functional execution leading to a major platform capability.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships fast: agency, urgency, and Slack
quotes.text: there's this potential shiny reward right in front of us, which is optimize user engagement, or whatever it is. And is that really the thing? Maybe the answer is yes. Maybe that is what is going to help us get to AGI sooner, but looking at it through that lens I think is always the first step of deciding any of these problems.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A prioritization lens that challenges default product thinking by filtering opportunities through mission impact rather than near-term metrics.

quotes.topic_title: How OpenAI ships fast: agency, urgency, and Slack
quotes.text: nobody cares if you have something great if they can't use it robust and reliably.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A blunt reliability-first principle for developer platforms that can guide roadmap trade-offs and sequencing.

quotes.topic_title: Planning, metrics, and scaling the organization
quotes.text: Yeah, I think the last public number was something around like 750 near the end of last year, 780 or something like that near the end of last year.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Gives a concrete data point on OpenAI’s reported headcount to anchor the scale of the organization.

quotes.topic_title: Planning, metrics, and scaling the organization
quotes.text: the actual research team, who seed most of the innovation that happens at OpenAI, is intentionally small.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Highlights an organizational design choice: keep the innovation-seeding research group small even while the company scales elsewhere.

quotes.topic_title: Planning, metrics, and scaling the organization
quotes.text: Most of the growth that OpenAI has seen is around our customer facing roles, our engineering roles to provide the infrastructure for ChatGPT and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: Shows a scaling pattern practitioners can copy: concentrate headcount growth in customer-facing and infrastructure functions rather than core research.

quotes.topic_title: Planning, metrics, and scaling the organization
quotes.text: in a world where you're constrained by the amount of GPU capacity that you have as a researcher, which is the case for open AI researchers, but also researchers everywhere else, each new researcher that you add is actually a net productivity loss for the research group unless that person is up-leveling everyone else in such a profound way that it increases the efficiency.
quotes.speaker: Logan Kilpatrick
quotes.context: A counterintuitive productivity model: under compute constraints, adding researchers can reduce output unless they materially raise the whole team’s efficiency.
